item.title: Pok√©mon FireRed And LeafGreen Are Topping The EShop Charts Despite Price Backlash
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon FireRed and LeafGreen are getting Switch ports on Friday, February 27. The 22-year-old Game Boy Advance remakes are widely considered the ‚Äúdefinitive‚Äù editions of the original games thanks to quality-of-life changes and added areas and quest lines. The games aren‚Äôt readily available right now, so you‚Äôd think this announcement would have been met with universal excitement. But that wasn‚Äôt the case, as the $20 ports were deemed too expensive by some. Nevertheless, the games are topping the eShop charts already.

I gotta admit, I do find the pearl clutching about the $20 price tag a bit surprising, but in my experience, it‚Äôs impossible to have discussions about video game pricing because everyone‚Äôs perception of what a dollar is worth is so different. As the Peak devs explained, video game pricing is all weird, vibes-based psychology that some companies have figured out and others just kind of ignore. 

$20 is what you might pay for a nice meal that you‚Äôll eat and then forget about, and here it gets you a 30+-hour game. But hey, I don‚Äôt know your economic situation, so I can‚Äôt speak to what $20 in your bank account means. I‚Äôm not here to judge anyone‚Äôs perception of money, I‚Äôm more concerned about how these conversations don‚Äôt seem to take that economic disparity into account.

‚Äî Protomario (@Protomario) February 22, 2026

I remember once talking to someone about the Mass Effect: Legendary Edition remasters, and they flatly said the collection‚Äôs $60 price point placed it out of their budget‚Ä¶but $50? That could be the sweet spot. A mere $10 could be the difference between them playing some of their favorite games again on modern hardware and not doing so.

FireRed and LeafGreen were $40 when they launched in 2004, but now if they‚Äôre anything short of free on Nintendo Switch Online, it‚Äôs the type of greed they talk about in the Bible. The irreconcilable way conflicting people talk about video game prices is born from those economic discrepancies, not everyone makes the same money, but also some people will just view any old game that costs money as a ripoff. It‚Äôs an unwinnable, unsolvable problem because everyone‚Äôs economic background is different, influenced by factors beyond their control, and is all based in a society that is wringing every cent out of all of us at any given moment. But that truth won‚Äôt stop the arguments from continuing, with anyone willing to pay $20 for an old game being deemed a shill and anyone unwilling being called poor. Whatever the case, many people are clearly willing to pay $20 to go back to Kanto again.

item.title: Is Wario Going To Be In The Super Mario Galaxy Movie?
item.content:encoded:
The Super Mario Galaxy Movie arrives in theaters in April. We know Yoshi, Bowser Jr., and Rosalina will be joining the sequel alongside the main returning characters, Mario, Luigi, Bowser, and Peach. But according to a new leak courtesy of a theater chain‚Äôs website, another new face is set to show up in the animated sequel.

As spotted by IGN, United Kingdom-based fancy movie theater chain Everyman recently posted a new text description for the upcoming blockbuster that just straight up lists Wario. The totally new, not-yet-announced-to-be-in-this-movie villain who is seemingly going to be a part of The Super Mario Galaxy Movie hasn‚Äôt shown up in any of Nintendo‚Äôs past marketing beats or trailers. Here‚Äôs the description:

‚ÄúAfter defeating Bowser and saving Brooklyn, Mario faces Wario and Bowser Jr.‚Äôs evil alliance. Now, alongside his friends and Yoshi, he must stop their plans for world domination.‚Äù

Well, that sure sounds like Wario is going to be in this movie! Of course, calling this a spoiler is probably inaccurate as it‚Äôs likely to be revealed in Nintendo and Universal‚Äôs own pre-release marketing rollout via a new teaser or something before the movie‚Äôs April 1 debut. But at least for now, Wario‚Äôs inclusion in the Mario movie sequel has yet to be announced. We do know that Chris Pratt, who voices Mario, has hinted that there are more unannounced characters left to be revealed. So he‚Äôs likely referencing Wario, assuming this leaked description is accurate. And if it is, it sounds like Wario will play a big role in the film alongside Bowser Jr.

Now, what I‚Äôm really excited about is that if Wario is in this movie, that means I can raise the chance of Nintendo‚Äôs horrible affront to nature, Waluigi, showing up in this flick from 1 percent to a solid 10 percent. Maybe more! How exciting.

item.title: The New Head Of Xbox Is Worried About Birthrates, But Says AI Will Save Us
item.content:encoded:
After the shock resignation of Phil Spencer and Sarah Bond from Xbox last week, the gaming world is attempting to piece together exactly what will happen next to Microsoft‚Äôs gaming brand, especially under the auspices of new leader Asha Sharma. Why has someone with a background in AI and not gaming been put at the helm? And wait, she said what about birthrates and AI?

Big tech‚Äôs obsession with birthrate figures is something that should certainly make you feel uncomfortable, given it‚Äôs usually about half a step removed from matters far more sinister. Which is why it‚Äôs so disappointing to hear Asha Sharma, in an interview on a podcast from five months ago, saying that the thing she thinks about the most‚Äîother than GPUs‚Äîis whether her son ‚Äúwill have classmates in the future.‚Äù (Thanks Sam Machkovech.) This is because, she says, ‚Äúfertility rates are declining, the average birthrate in the ‚Äô90s when we were growing up was, like, 3, and now it‚Äôs 2.3, and in 2050 it‚Äôs estimated to be below replacement.‚Äù This is strange on its own, and also completely wrong, but her next words make it far weirder. ‚ÄúI think that AI can have such a big effect on it, and already is.‚Äù

Sharma goes on to give examples of this, like how she‚Äôs heard about a hospital in London that‚Äôs using AI to improve the fertility success rate of IVF, the ‚Äúamazing story‚Äù of how ChatGPT 5 is ‚Äúhelping in healthcare,‚Äù and how Stanford was a big customer of hers, using AI for ‚Äútumor reviews.‚Äù

Of course, the reason for the declining birthrate in the U.S. is multifactorial, but almost certainly primarily about income. In the affluent ‚Äô90s, people felt confident about being able to afford two or three children, but in the 2020s that‚Äôs a far more costly prospect. If people in big tech were genuinely concerned about the number of children being born, their attention would be wholly focused on making American lives more affordable, providing better benefits and support, and increasing wages. And not, say, on replacing workers with ineffectual AI while driving industries that rely on paying low incomes.

Sharma‚Äôs numbers are way off, as it happens. The fertility rate wavered between 1.9 and 2.0 in the 1990s, and hasn‚Äôt been close to her claimed 3 since the mid-60s. It dipped as low as 1.6 after steady decline following the financial crash of 2008, but in recent years has begun to recover: it was back up to 1.8 in 2025. So in fact a difference of 0.1 since Sharma‚Äôs heyday of baby births.

But to put everyone‚Äôs minds at rest regarding those empty classrooms: As it turns out, we don‚Äôt just distribute however many children are around into the current number of classrooms. That would be a weird system. So even if birthrates were to suddenly halve, we‚Äôd just have‚Ä¶fewer schools. Am I really explaining this to the head of Xbox?
